node.title: How advice to a domestic violence survivor was compared to a restaurant recommendation
node.alt: Two women in a meeting room
node.description: When Emma disclosed domestic violence to a team leader at work, they responded by recommending a personal growth course. Emma says that advice, instead of getting appropriate domestic violence support, cost her financially and emotionally.
node.content:
["WARNING: This story contains content that some readers may find distressing.", "Emma* says her ex-partner assaulted her so viciously she thought she might die.\u00a0", "She said he held her against a door, by her throat, and threatened to smash a glass jar in her face.", "It was not the first time he abused her. She reported him to police.", "Soon after, in mid-2007, she went to work to ask her manager at Centrelink for time off.", "Her manager wasn't there but another colleague, a team leader who also held a role as a staff support officer, offered to talk to Emma.", "The team leader led her into a private meeting room and encouraged Emma to disclose her personal crisis which she had kept secret from work until now.", "\"After explaining the situation with my ex-partner and making my request for some time off, this team leader started talking about a course she had just completed that was meant to 'transform' your life and relationships,\" Emma later wrote in an email to Centrelink.", "She\u00a0left that meeting with a phone number\u00a0and went on to do a number of personal growth courses run by a large for-profit company, spending almost $3,000 in fees.", "She said the advice to do the course, instead of getting appropriate domestic violence support, cost her not just financially,\u00a0but emotionally as well.\u00a0", "It has been 14 years since that conversation, but Emma wants compensation and an apology from Centrelink and now plans to take her case to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.", "", "
Some employers provide\u00a0a guide for how best to respond to workplace disclosures of domestic\u00a0violence.(Supplied: Pexels)
", "
Workplaces key to advance gender equality
", "Emma's story highlights how employers have grappled with workplace responses to family and domestic violence, and it comes amid the national debate on Australia's treatment of women,\u00a0with workplaces a key focus.", "Between 55 and 70 per cent of women who are experiencing, or have experienced, violence are in the Australian workforce, according to Gabrielle Marchetti, principal lawyer with employment legal rights centre JobWatch.", "This equates to approximately 800,000 women, or around one in six female workers, she said.", "", "
Kate Jenkins leads several projects looking at the treatment of women in Australian workplaces.(ABC News: Jerry Rickard)
", "\"Workplaces are an important setting for Australia to advance gender equality, which is critical to reducing violence against women, ensure women's economic security and create opportunities for women in leadership,\" Sex Discrimination Commissioner Kate Jenkins said.", "She said \"Australia has taken positive steps\" to help women escape violence while keeping a job, but was\u00a0\"concerned there are no comprehensive and consistent workplace protections across all Australian jurisdictions for employees who experience family and domestic violence\".", "\"This is an important issue, and the commission has made relevant recommendations to the Australian government,\" she said.", "These include supporting workplaces to have relevant policies and programs, and introduce uniform entitlements to paid\u00a0family and domestic violence leave \u2014 a topic of live debate.", "All workers can currently access five days of unpaid violence leave under national employment laws,\u00a0but some advocates want this changed to 10 days of paid leave.", "Proposed legislation came before federal parliament earlier this year, just three days before a national women's safety summit, but it was knocked back.", "The Fair Work Commission\u00a0is also considering if paid violence leave should be set out in the\u00a0job\u00a0terms and conditions \u2014 or modern awards \u2014\u00a0in some industries and occupations, while other private and government employers already offer paid leave in specific agreements.\u00a0", "Violence leave entitlements were not in place when Emma went through her crisis.", "Instead, she used up her personal leave\u00a0to handle her situation.", "", "
Domestic violence leave wasn't available to Emma at the time.(Supplied: Services Australia)
", "
Costs of the wrong advice
", "But a key\u00a0part of the workplace response that impacted Emma was the advice from the Centrelink team leader to do the course, given at a time when she was vulnerable.", "The commercial course, external to and not approved by Centrelink, was a personal and professional development program, not tailored to\u00a0domestic violence victim-survivors.\u00a0", "Emma said during the program she was encouraged to change things in her life which were making her unhappy.\u00a0", "At that point, Emma said she had been working at Centrelink for several\u00a0years and was listed for a promotion.", "She wanted a child but when the relationship ended because of violence, she felt it was unlikely she would have a baby.", "Her work \u2014 which included processing family tax benefits and baby bonuses \u2014 made her think about her personal situation, exacerbating her distress.", "", "
A complaints scheme ruled the advice given to Emma at work was personal.(AAP)
", "She had requested a change in duties that hadn't eventuated. So, with this in mind and shortly after the course, she quit.", "She then went through periods of underemployment and unemployment. Her income fluctuated.", "Emma did not seek medical help to deal with the trauma from violence until nearly 10 years after the 2007 assault.", "A letter from her therapist in 2017 said Emma \"was not, due to her mental state at the time, in full control of her decision to resign from her job [with] Centrelink and forgo and lose all of her benefits and entitlements\".", "
How to react to a disclosure at work
", "Experts say you should not provide personal advice to a colleague who discloses violence, and should\u00a0instead refer them to specialist\u00a0violence services.", "There are several publicly available guides\u00a0on how managers or staff should respond, including one from national violence prevention agency Our Watch.", "Our Watch chief executive Patty Kinnersly said the most important thing to do was \"listen to the person, show you believe them and take the disclosure seriously\".", "
Advice likened to a restaurant recommendation
", "In addition to the misplaced advice, Emma believes the response from her former employer to subsequent complaints should have been more compassionate and approached through an understanding of domestic violence as a workplace issue.\u00a0", "Her first compensation request was in 2009, two years after she quit Centrelink, when she realised the advice to do the personal growth courses was wrong and she should not have resigned.", "", "
Documentation, provided by Emma to the ABC, details multiple complaints and compensation requests.\u00a0(ABC News: Jarrod Fankhauser)
", "She wrote an email to\u00a0Centrelink seeking to be reimbursed for the course costs as they were \"recommended by a Centrelink Team Leader and Staff Support Officer at a time when I was incredibly vulnerable and was seeking support from within the organisation\".", "Centrelink determined they were not approved courses of study, and there were no \"special circumstances\" that \"justify reimbursement\", documentation shows.", "Nearly six years went by. Emma's life moved on, but the past started to resurface. She said she began having flashbacks about her ex-partner.", "\"I realised that I hadn't dealt with any of it,\" Emma said.", "\"I stuffed around with [the courses] when really, what I should have been doing was getting the support that I needed for the abuse that I'd experienced.\"", "In 2016 she wrote another email, this time to the Department of Human Services, seeking to be reimbursed for the total financial loss she felt she had incurred.", "The Department said because Centrelink made a decision in 2009, and Emma had not provided any new information, the agency was \"unable to take any further action\".", "", "
All workers experiencing family and domestic violence have some legal rights.(ABC News: Michael Clements )
", "Emma then requested the Department review that decision via a complaints scheme for commonwealth government entities.", "The final decision in 2017 noted there was \"no significant factual dispute about the conversation in 2007\", but the advice given to Emma was of a \"personal nature\" and not given \"in the course of [the staff support officer's] duty\".", "\"[Staff support officers'] official responsibilities extended to providing support to staff in relation to matters concerning their work, it did not extend to provide counselling about personal crisis such as domestic violence and separation, or about personal growth training\", the decision said.", "The letter also stated that \"[staff support officer] compared her recommendation about [the course provider] to a recommendation about a restaurant she enjoyed\" and advised Emma to contact the Commonwealth Ombudsman if she was not satisfied.", "Emma has always disagreed with the decision, and described the restaurant comparison as \"inapt and absurd\".", "Services Australia general manager Hank Jongen said the agency, which Centrelink sits under, couldn't comment on the specifics of this case.", "", "
Mr Jongen says the agency takes family and domestic violence seriously.(Supplied: Services Australia)
", "But Mr Jongen said Services Australia \"takes the wellbeing of all staff extremely seriously\" and the department has a domestic and family violence strategy that includes policies, processes, staff training, access to the Employee Assistance Program, leave options and a dedicated contact line.", "\"We prioritise providing a supportive, flexible and safe workplace for everyone, including those affected by family and domestic violence,\" he said.", "At the time the team leader met Emma and recommended\u00a0the course, Centrelink did not have its\u00a0current domestic violence strategy, including staff training, in place.", "
Is domestic\u00a0violence support available in your workplace?
", "All workers experiencing family and domestic violence have legal rights, Ms Marchetti said.", "In addition to\u00a0unpaid violence leave, employees can request\u00a0flexible working arrangements. Permanent workers also have access to paid personal or carers leave.", "Occupational workplace health and safety laws require employers to provide a safe working environment and there are also other legal protections for people experiencing violence, such as against unfair dismissal.", "But beyond those minimum legal requirements and entitlements in specific agreements, workplace responses to family and domestic\u00a0violence can vary depending on the employer. That response can include paid leave, staff training, policies, procedures \u2014\u00a0or none of those things.", "The Champions of Change Coalition, founded by former sex discrimination commissioner Elizabeth Broderick AO, has produced detailed reports on domestic and family violence and workplace responses.", "Its most recent report, released\u00a0in November,\u00a0calls\u00a0on workplaces to do more to address\u00a0domestic violence, which is a workplace health and safety issue.", "Our Watch recommends employers start by implementing a whole-of-organisation approach through a set of standards that aims to prevent violence and promote a supportive workplace culture.", "These standards, plus any policies, procedures and safety plans, should be implemented through staff training.", "\"This means everyone is involved, from the board to operations, in order to build genuine and sustained change to organisational policies, systems and culture,\" Ms\u00a0Kinnersly said.\u00a0", "*Name has been changed to\u00a0protect identity."]
